questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the Global Hunger Index? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Infant Mortality Rate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Global Hunger Index is calculated based on the following indicators:
  • • Till 2014 – following 3 indicators
  • • After 2016, the Global Hunger Index calculation was done using above four indicators, which do not include the infant mortality rate directly.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. U5MR: Because the under-five mortality rate is one of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.
  • • Option
  • • A. U5MR:
  • • Option B. Malnutrition (wasting, stunting): Because both child wasting and child stunting are part of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.
  • • Option
  • • B. Malnutrition (wasting, stunting):
  • • Option C. Inadequate food supply: Because, while inadequate food supply can contribute to child undernourishment, it is not directly used as an indicator in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.
  • • Option
  • • C. Inadequate food supply:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Global Hunger Index is calculated using four indicators: child undernourishment, under-five mortality rate, child wasting, and child stunting. The infant mortality rate is not directly included in the calculation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old shipyard worker presents with increasing shortness of breath and a persistent dry cough over the past year. He has worked with insulation materials for 35 years. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally. A chest X-ray reveals a "ground glass" appearance. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with these findings? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Asbestosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asbestosis is associated with a "ground glass" appearance on chest X-ray and occurs in workers exposed to asbestos over long periods.
  • ➤ Asbestosis

questions.text: A woman presents to a clinic with her son, Ram, who has developed symptoms consistent with Measles, including fever and rash. She mentions that Ram's brother, Shyam, exhibited similar symptoms a few days earlier. Which of the following statements regarding the situation are accurate? (INICET MAY 2022) Ram is the index case Shyam is primary case Ram got infected from Shyam If mother had reported when Shyam got infection, Ram could have been vaccinated
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Index case → First case that comes to the notice of investigator. Primary case → First case of a disease in a population. Incubation period of measles infection is 7 to 18 days Vaccine can be given within 72 hours of post-exposure and immunoglobulin can be given up to 6 days’ post-exposure.
  • ➤ Index case → First case that comes to the notice of investigator.
  • ➤ Index case
  • ➤ Primary case → First case of a disease in a population.
  • ➤ Primary case
  • ➤ Incubation period of measles infection is 7 to 18 days
  • ➤ Vaccine can be given within 72 hours of post-exposure and immunoglobulin can be given up to 6 days’ post-exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding a confounding factor? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: It can be reduced by matching

options.label: B
options.text: It is associated individually with both cause and effect

options.label: C
options.text: It is distributed equally in both study and control groups

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.correct_answer: C. It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is distributed equally in both study and control groups

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Confounding can be removed by
  • ➤ Confounding can be removed by
  • ➤ 1. Matching → MC used /simplest method
  • ➤ 2. Randomization → 2nd Best Method
  • ➤ 3. Restriction
  • ➤ 4. Stratification
  • ➤ 5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)
  • ➤ 6. Stratified Randomization → Overall Best Method

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes, recently diagnosed with end-stage renal disease (stage 5) and on hemodialysis, seeks dietary advice. Which of the following characterizes the ideal renal feed for him? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Low volume, high calories

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An ideal diet for patients with end-stage renal disease should be low in volume to manage fluid balance and high in calories to prevent malnutrition and wasting.
  • ➤ An ideal diet for patients with end-stage renal disease should be low in volume to manage fluid balance and high in calories to prevent malnutrition and wasting.

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other group consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. Then Bladder cancer cases were identified from both the groups in the current time. What type of study is being performed? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Retrospective cohort study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A retrospective cohort study involves examining historical data to investigate the relationship between exposure and outcomes. In this scenario, it is used to study the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer among workers over a 20-year period.

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Zinc phosphide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation -
  • • The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.
  • • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system. Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water. General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.
  • • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • • Zinc phosphide
  • • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder
  • • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stratified random sampling is the best method to ensure that all subgroups within a diverse population are adequately represented in the study.

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is keenly interested in understanding the relationship between lung cancer and smoking habits. After conducting an extensive study and analyzing his data, he finds that the attributable risk is 90%. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this result? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

options.label: B
options.text: 90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

options.label: C
options.text: 90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated

options.label: D
options.text: 10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.correct_answer: A. 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population
  • ➤ Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure
  • ➤ Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tracking of blood pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracking of blood pressure describes the observation that individuals maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values from childhood to adulthood. This means that blood pressure levels tend to remain consistent relative to peers over time.
  • ➤ Tracking of blood pressure

questions.text: Based on the depiction in the accompanying image, which model of disease causation is being illustrated? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sufficient component cause model

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sufficient component cause model illustrates how multiple factors contribute to disease causation, with some factors being necessary components in multiple causal pathways.

questions.text: During a busy day at the outpatient clinic, a nurse accidentally sustains a needle stick injury while drawing blood from a patient known to have HIV. She asks for guidance on immediate management steps to mitigate her risk of acquiring the infection. Which of the following recommendations would NOT be appropriate? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Washing hands with soap and water

options.label: C
options.text: Measure baseline viral markers of health care worker immediately

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Administration of tenofovir monotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For needle stick injuries involving HIV exposure, a triple drug regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis is recommended, not monotherapy. Immediate washing, baseline viral markers, and follow-up testing are also critical components of the management protocol.
  • ➤ For needle stick injuries involving HIV exposure, a triple drug regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis is recommended, not monotherapy.
  • ➤ Immediate washing, baseline viral markers, and follow-up testing are also critical components of the management protocol.

questions.text: As per Nutrition Guidelines of India, a 55 kg woman needs how many grams of proteins? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 45 grams

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the nutrition guidelines of India, the protein requirement for adults is based on body weight.
  • • The recommended daily protein intake is 0.83 grams per kilogram of body weight. For an adult reference Indian woman weighing 55 kg, this translates to approximately 45 grams of protein per day (0.83 grams/kg/day x 55 kg = 45.65 grams/day, rounded to 45 grams).
  • • Additional Information –
  • • Additional Information –
  • • The recommended daily energy intake: [NEW GUIDELINES 2021-22]
  • • The recommended daily energy intake: [NEW GUIDELINES 2021-22]

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 55 kg woman requires approximately 45 grams of protein per day according to the nutrition guidelines of India.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Early diagnosis and treatment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early diagnosis and treatment (secondary prevention) are the most effective methods for preventing the progression of breast cancer, as they allow for early detection and intervention, significantly improving the chances of successful treatment and reducing mortality rates.

questions.text: According to triage, which of the following colors indicates the highest priority? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Red

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the triage system, the red color indicates the highest priority. The triage categories and their corresponding colors are as follows:
  • • Red : Category 1, highest priority. Patients requiring immediate resuscitation or life-saving surgery within 0 to 6 hours.
  • • Red
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Yellow : Category 2, high priority. Possible resuscitation or possible surgery within 6 to 24 hours.
  • • Option B. Yellow
  • • Option C. Green : Category 3, low priority. Ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries.
  • • Option C. Green
  • • Option D. Black : Least priority, includes dead and moribund patients.
  • • Option D. Black
  • • The red category, which is assigned to patients requiring immediate life-saving intervention, is the highest priority in the triage system.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 38-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents with altered sensorium and unsteady gait. Vitamin deficiency most likely to be seen in this case would be (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitamin B1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency in chronic alcoholics can lead to Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, presenting with neurological symptoms such as altered sensorium and unsteady gait.
  • ➤ Note - Vit. B1 deficiency also leads to Beri Beri in polished rice eaters
  • ➤ Note - Vit. B1 deficiency also leads to Beri Beri in polished rice eaters

questions.text: While numerous animals play a role in the transmission of rabies, dogs stand out as the most common ones. Moreover, the impact of this disease is often more in children. Given this understanding, what approach would be both economically efficient and rational to reduce the occurrence of rabies? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Testing all the dogs for rabies

options.label: B
options.text: Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs

options.label: D
options.text: Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance

questions.correct_answer: B. Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reducing the stray dog population and vaccinating all dogs is the most economically efficient and rational approach to reduce the occurrence of rabies. This strategy directly targets the primary source of infection and helps prevent the spread of the disease.

questions.text: A city school board is determining the minimum classroom space per student for safety and well-being. What is the minimum per capita space that should be available for each child in a school classroom based on public health guidelines? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. > 10 Sqft

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ School health service guidelines recommendations are:
  • ➤ One class room for maximum 40 students Minus type desk Doors and windows ≥ 25% of floor area 1 urinal /60 student, 1 latrine/100 student. Natural light from left side Minimum area 10 sq. ft. per student for sitting. School health examination every 6 months. Walls should be white in colour. Canteen should be present if number of students are more than 250.
  • ➤ One class room for maximum 40 students
  • ➤ Minus type desk
  • ➤ Doors and windows ≥ 25% of floor area
  • ➤ 1 urinal /60 student, 1 latrine/100 student.
  • ➤ Natural light from left side
  • ➤ Minimum area 10 sq. ft. per student for sitting.
  • ➤ School health examination every 6 months.
  • ➤ Walls should be white in colour.
  • ➤ Canteen should be present if number of students are more than 250.

questions.text: As a medical student, you're learning about the margin of error and its relationship with sample size. With three studies of different sizes (Sample 1: 1000, Sample 2: 800, Sample 3: 600), how would you order the expected margins of error from largest to smallest? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3>2>1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The margin of error in a study is inversely related to the square root of the sample size. This relationship implies that a larger sample size will generally lead to a smaller margin of error, assuming other variables like variance remain constant.
  • ➤ The margin of error in a study is inversely related to the square root of the sample size.
  • ➤ This relationship implies that a larger sample size will generally lead to a smaller margin of error, assuming other variables like variance remain constant.

questions.text: You are a researcher studying global mortality rates, and you notice substantial differences in the age structures of various countries. Recognizing that direct comparisons could be misleading due to these differences, you explore methods to equalize or adjust the mortality data to get a more accurate comparative view. In your research, you come across the term "standardized age mortality ratio." Which of the following best describes this concept? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution

options.label: B
options.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution

options.label: C
options.text: Removal of bias due to different age group population in different countries

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate age structure of different countries

questions.correct_answer: A. Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The standardized age mortality ratio adjusts the death rate of a population to a standard age distribution, allowing for more accurate comparisons between populations with different age structures.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Types of Standardized Death Rates
  • ➤ Types of Standardized Death Rates
  • ➤ Direct standardization:
  • ➤ Direct standardization:
  • ➤ Method: Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied on a standard population Total expected deaths calculated Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate Feasibility: Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR) Availability of population in each age group
  • ➤ Method: Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied on a standard population Total expected deaths calculated Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • ➤ Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied on a standard population Total expected deaths calculated Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • ➤ Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied
  • ➤ on a standard population
  • ➤ Total expected deaths calculated
  • ➤ Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • ➤ Feasibility: Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR) Availability of population in each age group
  • ➤ Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR) Availability of population in each age group
  • ➤ Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR)
  • ➤ Availability of population in each age group
  • ➤ Indirect standardization: Standardized mortality ratio (SMR): Is simplest and most useful form
  • ➤ Indirect standardization:
  • ➤ Method: Calculate expected deaths, assuming that study group experiences the death rates of a standard population Feasibility: Permits adjustment where age-specific rates are not available or are unstable because of small numbers Examples of indirect Standardization: Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100 Life Table Analysis Survival Analysis
  • ➤ Method: Calculate expected deaths, assuming that study group experiences the death rates of a standard population
  • ➤ Feasibility: Permits adjustment where age-specific rates are not available or are unstable because of small numbers
  • ➤ Examples of indirect Standardization:
  • ➤ Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100
  • ➤ Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100
  • ➤ Life Table Analysis
  • ➤ Life Table Analysis
  • ➤ Survival Analysis
  • ➤ Survival Analysis

questions.text: In a nuclear family, the oldest person is 67 years old, his wife is 59 years old. They have a son who is 30 years old, and the son’s wife is 27 years old. They also have a grandchild who is 5 years old. Calculate the dependency ratio for the family: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 66%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The dependency ratio is calculated as the number of dependents (below 15 years and above 65 years) divided by the number of working-age individuals (15-65 years), multiplied by 100.
  • ➤ Dependency ratio measures the ‘need for society to provide for its’ younger and older groups’

questions.text: After a road traffic accident case has been admitted, there is a blood spillage on the hospital floor. Which type of disinfectant would you select for cleaning the floor? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sodium hypochlorite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For effective disinfection of surfaces contaminated with blood spills, sodium hypochlorite is the preferred choice due to its broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity and ability to neutralize blood-borne pathogens.

questions.text: An esteemed research institute recently conducted a comprehensive study on individuals diagnosed with HIV to understand the progression and current health status of the participants. questions.explanation:

This provides a more accurate assessment of the overall average CD4 count, crucial for understanding the immune status in a clinical setting.

questions.text: In a community of 100000 population, 105 children were born in a year, out of which 5 were still births and 2 died within 6 months after birth and another 2 died within next 6 months. The IMR (Infant Mortality Rate) is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 40

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is calculated by dividing the total number of infant deaths (deaths within the first year of life) by the total number of live births, and multiplying the result by 1,000.
  • • In this case, the given information is:
  • • Total births in a year = 105 Stillbirths = 5 Infant deaths within the first 6 months = 2 Infant deaths within the next 6 months = 2
  • • Total births in a year = 105
  • • Stillbirths = 5
  • • Infant deaths within the first 6 months = 2
  • • Infant deaths within the next 6 months = 2
  • • To calculate the IMR:
  • • 1. Calculate the number of live births:
  • • Total live births = Total births - Stillbirths
  • • Total live births = 105 - 5 = 100
  • • 2. Calculate the total number of infant deaths:
  • • Total infant deaths = Infant deaths within the first 6 months + Infant deaths within the next 6 months
  • • Total infant deaths = 2 + 2 = 4
  • • 3. Calculate the IMR using the formula:
  • • IMR = (Total infant deaths / Total live births) × 1,000
  • • IMR = (4 / 100) × 1,000
  • • IMR = 40
  • • Therefore, the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for this community is 40 per 1,000 live births.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is a crucial indicator that represents the number of infant deaths (deaths within the first year of life) per 1,000 live births in a given population or community.

  • • The Ayushman Bharat program has two main components:
  • • Health and Wellness Centres (HWCs) - Create a network of health, wellness infrastructure delivering comprehensive primary healthcare services Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY). PM-JAY provides an insurance cover of Rs 5 Lacs per family per year for secondary and tertiary hospitalization. This program is targeted towards the below poverty line (BPL) population, aiming to cover around 10.74 crore families.

questions.text: A medical student accidentally drops a sphygmomanometer, causing mercury spill on the floor. What is the most appropriate method to manage this spill? (INICET MAY 2022)

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to you with her mother, reporting abdominal discomfort and is found to be 12 weeks pregnant based on a positive urine pregnancy test. As a medical professional, what would be your initial course of action? ( INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: Get consent from mother for P/V

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inform Police

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In many jurisdictions, pregnancy in a minor may be considered evidence of statutory rape or sexual abuse, hence, informing the police is crucial for legal proceedings and safeguarding the minor.
  • • Other Option
  • • Other Option
  • • Option A. Start examining: Although a medical examination is necessary, it must be conducted with proper legal and parental consent, especially considering the age and the situation's sensitivity.
  • • Option A. Start examining:
  • • Option C. Preserve clothing: This could be necessary in a case where forensic evidence needs to be gathered, especially if there was recent assault. However, this would follow legal reporting.
  • • Option C. Preserve clothing:
  • • Option D. Take consent from mother: Consent is crucial, especially for minors. However, it does not preclude the obligation to report statutory rape or sexual abuse to authorities.
  • • Option D. Take consent from mother:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective :
  • • When dealing with potentially criminal situations involving minors, such as a young teenager's pregnancy, the first step is to ensure the situation is addressed legally and safely. Informing law enforcement and ensuring proper medical and legal procedures safeguard the minor's health and legal rights.

questions.text: What is the purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adolescents

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The HEADSS assessment is a structured psychosocial interview technique specifically designed to be used with adolescents . The purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation is to provide a comprehensive framework for obtaining a detailed history from adolescents. It covers several key areas, including:
  • • adolescents
  • • Home & Environment- Understanding the adolescent's living conditions, relationships with family members, and any issues at home. Education and Employment - Gathering information about the adolescent's school performance, educational aspirations, and employment status. Activities - Identifying the adolescent's involvement in extracurricular activities, hobbies, and how they spend their free time. Drugs - Assessing the use of drugs, alcohol, and tobacco, including experimentation and regular use. Sexuality - Discussing topics related to sexual activity, orientation, and practices to ensure safe and healthy sexual behaviors. Suicide /Depression - Screening for mood issues, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health concerns.
  • • Home & Environment- Understanding the adolescent's living conditions, relationships with family members, and any issues at home.
  • • Home
  • • Education and Employment - Gathering information about the adolescent's school performance, educational aspirations, and employment status.
  • • Education and Employment
  • • Activities - Identifying the adolescent's involvement in extracurricular activities, hobbies, and how they spend their free time.
  • • Activities
  • • Drugs - Assessing the use of drugs, alcohol, and tobacco, including experimentation and regular use.
  • • Drugs
  • • Sexuality - Discussing topics related to sexual activity, orientation, and practices to ensure safe and healthy sexual behaviors.
  • • Sexuality
  • • Suicide /Depression - Screening for mood issues, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health concerns.
  • • Suicide
  • • Now Extended to become – HEEADSS
  • • Now Extended to become – HEEADSS
  • • E – Eating and Exercise
  • • E – Eating and Exercise
  • • S - Safety
  • • S - Safety
  • • Educational objective : The HEADSS assessment helps healthcare providers establish rapport with adolescent patients, identify risk factors, and discuss sensitive issues in a non-judgmental, confidential manner. This can lead to better health outcomes by addressing potential problems early.
  • • Educational objective :

questions.text: According to our national immunization schedule, when should the first dose of the Hepatitis B vaccine ideally be administered to a neonate? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. At birth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first dose of the Hepatitis B vaccine is administered at birth as part of the national immunization schedule. This early vaccination is crucial for preventing mother-to-child transmission of the Hepatitis B virus, which can occur during birth or shortly after. Administering the vaccine at birth significantly reduces the risk of the newborn contracting Hepatitis B, a critical intervention in areas with a high prevalence of the disease.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company conducted a double-blind clinical trial comparing a new antidiabetic drug to a placebo. The study enrolled an equal number of participants in both arms. Based on the data below, what are the Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) and Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) for adverse effects? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) RRR 11%, ARR 1%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) reflects the proportionate reduction in risk between two groups, while the Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) provides the difference in risk between them

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the results of a study comparing two antihypertensive drugs in an Indian population. She comes across the term "p-value" in her statistical analyses. questions.text: A study was undertaken to estimate the effect of a drug ‘D’ in three different groups – Plants, Animals, and Human beings. Samples were chosen randomly out of the three groups individually. This is a type of? (NEET PG 2024)
